author: User 112
text: When I was young, before I got interested in actively seeking out new comedians to enjoy I would watch panel shows, and I mean preteens level of young. One such panel show was 8 out of 10 Cats, it was this panel show that showed me just how brilliant comedians could be, it was 8 Out of 10 Cats that got me actively interested in seeking comedy. And I have to say it was Sean Lock that did that for me. I've had a lot of hard times since that first time watching Sean be a brilliant funny man, and in those times I turn to comedy, I imagine I would have found comedy somewhere down the line, but the man that introduced me to that world was Sean Lock, and him not being on this earth is so incredibly unfair. Thank you Sean, for showing me that the world isn't always doom and gloom, and even when it is, there's usually a laugh to be found somewhere.

author: User 116
text: Sean Lock is one comedian on my VERY small list of jokesters that make me laugh constantly, no matter how many times I re-watch his best bits. He was the type of comedian that, you could recite one of his jokes along with him and despite knowing the punchline, his personality and delivery shone through, making you laugh every time, no matter what. The type of comedian that, you knew, the moment his brain engaged, you could see his eyes flash to life when asked a question or was prompted, what was gonna come out of his mouth was always gonna be comedy gold. You were nearly laughing before he finished speaking because, knowing he was always on it, you were gonna laugh anyway. The impact he had on his friends and his audiences was always a sight to behold, you always felt and sense of true friendship between everyone and the raw reaction he got from them whenever he spoke was always so wholesome and heartwarming. He inspired you to be that kind of person to you OWN friends. If you're the "comedian" or "jester" of your friend group, he made you feel like you should do the same thing for your own friends, make them laugh and feel good whenever you can, or even doing the same thing for strangers, be it being a madman in public and making strangers laugh from your sheer weirdness, doing stand-up yourselves, or even just making content on YouTube and hoping that you can make, at the very least, ONE person laugh from what you do. It takes a special kind of comedian to make you feel like that after a handful of jokes, but Lord knows, Sean Lock was one of them, and it's such a shame that one of Britain's best, was taken so soon. I just hope he knows how much he's loved and how much he's dearly missed. Rest in Peace Mr. Sean Lock, may you be reunited with Claude way up there with the greats.

author: User 121
text: As a Canadian I didn‚Äôt have the privilege of seeing Sean Lock on TV all the time. I first discovered Sean Lock in June 2018 just after I had been hospitalized for severe degenerative disc disease in my spine and chronic sciatica. I was completely incapacitated for a month, I couldn‚Äôt move off of the livingroom floor and all I did was watch 8 Out Of 10 Cats Does Countdown on YouTube. The entire time I was dealing with my back and not able to move my cat Cheshire never left my side, not even for a second. My mom even had to bring her a litter box and food beside me because she didn‚Äôt want to leave me alone. Then in January 2019 my cat Cheshire died in my arms after she had been struggling with congestive heart failure, as she was trying to take her final breath she grabbed on my eye with her claws and pierced my eyelids with her claws, that of course sent me to the hospital. I couldn‚Äôt do much at all when I got home because there was a lot of damage to my eye and it was completely swollen shut. I also had no coordination to walk around because I could only see out of one eye. I was going through so much and I didn‚Äôt have time to process my cat dying and me being hurt so all I did was watch Countdown. Then in October 2019 my family and I suffered our biggest loss ever when 4 family members ages ranging from 97 years old to 8 years old all died for different reasons all in the same month. Sean Locks humour is what got me through that extremely tough time. My brother and I stayed up most nights and that show is what helped us distract ourselves from everything that just happened. I will forever be grateful to Sean Lock and the whole cast of 8 Out Of 10 Cats Does Countdown. He will be extremely missed. RIP Sean Lock üíî

World War III Has Begun; How It Unfolds Depends on Us

We think of the Russia-Ukraine war as a local conflict, but it is much more than that; it is a global war on multiple fronts. The war is not only a military conflict; it is also an economic war of attrition. With skyrocketing gas prices and shortage of staples, people all over the world are feeling the consequences of the war.

This war is transforming the entire modus operandi of humanity. Since the dawn of time, we have been accustomed to living by the motto, ‚Äúsurvival of the fittest.‚Äù By and large, the rule was that the strong determined the rules, and the rules were often abusive toward the weak. Now, it seems like a new mindset has set in: Wanting something and being strong enough to take it does not mean that the world will accept it.

The war, therefore, is being fought on the inside no less, and perhaps more than on the outside. Our very makeup is changing from abusive to cooperative, from narcissistic to altruistic.

It hurts, and it will not happen without a struggle, but it is irreversible. This is the path of our evolution toward the purpose of our creation‚Äîto encompass within us all of creation. To do that, we must come to care for it, just as a mother encompasses her child through her maternal love.

The struggle to transition from our current uncaring and mean approach to all creations but ourselves, into wise and compassionate beings is called ‚Äúthe war of Gog and Magog‚Äù or Armageddon.

Since the war is about our inner makeup, we can fight it within us. If we object to struggling with ourselves over who will rule‚Äîthe ego or love‚Äîthe physical reality will force us to choose love nonetheless. However, it will do so by hurting us in a very physical way.

The war in Eastern Europe is nothing compared to what we might have to endure if we resist the process. The horrific descriptions of our sages and prophets hint at it, and we would not want to live through it.

Alternatively, we can fight this war within us without firing a single bullet. The choice is in our hands. All we need is to continue in the same direction that nature is already leading us: toward connection. If we make an effort to care for one another, even though initially we don‚Äôt, then we are moving in the right direction. If we try to resolve conflicts not with guns or even legal battles, but by strengthening the care and friendship between us, then we are saving lives and sparing torments from countless people.

In conclusion, let us try to rise above the hatred and see the human on the other side, who suffers too. Let us think that this war was given to us so we would think about each other more than we have so far. After all, were it not for this war, we would not notice one another. Now that it is here, we are no longer indifferent. Although our feelings our currently negative, now that we are aware of them, we can work on them together and turn them around. These are the wars of the Messiah who moshech [Hebrew: pulls] us out of the ego, and into mutual love .

author: User 176
text:
A fitting tribute to someone more than just a Comedian - but a wonderful human being.

I met Sean once a couple of months into a new job at an entertainment venue sometime around late 2010. 

After greeting him upon arrival, he‚Äôd already clocked my name, as I was there to facilitate anything he may have needed. As the House was being seated, I was tasked with giving him his ‚Äú5 Minute Cue‚Äù for showtime. I popped backstage and was greeted by the sight of Sean in white boxer shorts with his trousers around his ankles hopping about rushing to get them on. I didn‚Äôt even have time to say anything before he immediately quipped: ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow, I normally charge extra for this part of the show P****, but seen as it‚Äôs you...‚Äù

Just as Lisa Tarbuck said in the VT, people who make us laugh share a rare and special gift that leaves a lasting impression on us. Mine was a brief moment just shared between he and I, and I realise now how special that was - he didn‚Äôt have to make a joke about it, it was just who he was, and the world was a better place for him being in it. I think we can all pay that forward. It‚Äôs the least we could do.

So yeah‚Ä¶THANK YOU SEAN. x

I'd consider myself something of an aficionado of British Comedy, but nobody else has ever made me laugh like Sean Lock. His timing and delivery were perfect, but what really made him great was the fact he genuinely seemed to enjoy what he did. He found the whole thing as funny as you did. Watching him was like that moment where you and a friend can't stop laughing, and eventually forget the original joke and just get lost in the moment.

An absolute master at work.

author: User 198
text:
I hadn't cried in many  years until I heard about the passing of the great Sean Lock. I've lost close friends in car crashes, and to diseases.... but this one struck me so hard because he brought me so much laughter and happiness and had so much more to give. I'm not sure why I didn't cry for my friends. I feel like they were so close to me and they would say "no need to cry, my friend, just keep living" or something philosophical like that.... but from Sean, watching him from across the world.... I had no idea how to express myself other than let it all out.
R.I.P. Sean Lock. Will always love you and your brilliant comedy.

I went to the comedy store about 26 years ago. The first guy that came out , stood in front of the mic, waved his hands over some imaginary object and said ‚Äú I‚Äôve just fixed a V8 engine‚Äù then he produced an imaginary magnifying glass and started to kill imaginary ants with it using the suns rays. Then many years later he appeared on Tv and I recognised him... it was Sean, I always remember that guy that fixed the V8 engine on stage and wondered if I would ever see him again, thankfully I and the rest of the world were able to marvel at this comic genius for many more years.

If there were ever a human being that was at peace with this weird, terrifying and horrible thing we dealt with every day, it had to be Sean.
Of course, none of us can know, and to speculate seems disrespectful.
But I think we can all agree that on 8 out of 10 Cats, and Cats does Countdown, Sean always had this thing about him. It was like he knew your secrets and couldn't give a shit.
I know we all miss him, but we can probably all agree that that if he know how much we've all cried, and have a shit about him... He'd laugh us into oblivion. His whimsical way about things always put us at ease, but when Sean gave a shit, it really seemed to matter.

author: User 270
text: No celebrity death has ever affected me. I was always like: "Well, it's sad, but I don't know them personally". Until Sean Lock. The whole bit on Countdown, when he did "The rectum of the year" is literally one of the funniest things I have watched in my life, only made even better by Claudia Winkleman sitting beside him and losing it just like I was.

replies.text: On a serious note comments like this make me feel like I‚Äôm devoid of real human emotion. I loved Rik Mayal, drop dead Fred, Bottom all that jazz however I don‚Äôt get cut up thinking about him being dead. Do you genuinely still think about him a decade after his death and feel genuine deep sadness? How do you cope when you think about the millions of starving Africans who‚Äôs deaths are completely preventable? How do you get out of bed in the morning when you are reminded of actual close family members who have died? Is your life just one long miserable pit of depression or do people just say stuff like this to pretend they‚Äôre deep and emotional? Genuinely interested.

author: User 335
text: When someone like Sean is taken from us, it actually highlights their value to all of us. We live in dark times - 30 seconds to midnight etc. Actors do their best to distract us, but its comedians that truly put a smile on us. I like the various members of the 8 out of 10 crew for different reasons. But Sean's bitterness and intelligence was very special. As they mentioned, a comedian that can make comedians laugh is extremely rare. He is missed, but I'm pretty sure he would give us one "Those" looks and tell us to get the hell on with things rather than moping... And they should change the name of Carrot In A Box to the Sean Lock Challenge.

author: User 343
text: The one great thing I appreciated about Sean Lock's humour was that he was never dishonest. He was silly, sarcastic, self-deprecating, and sometimes crude, but the sentiment was always straight to the point. author: User 799
text:
I have two favourite clips of Sean, both from Cats Does Countdown and both when he's partnered with Miles Jupp.

In the first, the unforgettable whelk incident. There's nothing more to say there, I feel.

The second is Miles' first (?) appearance and as his mascot, he brings out a photograph which he insists was left to him by his grandfather - the picture is Sean's headshot, and Sean laughs hysterically and is unable to pull himself together for several minutes.

That told me everything about the kind of person Sean was. Just as is said in the video, every time he laughed was like getting an approving nod from the headmaster, and you could see that even though the joke had completely blind-sided him he wasn't ashamed to admit it and laugh along with his friend.

So long, Sean. Mind how you go.

author: User 833
text: I watch a lot of comedy. TV shows, standups, films... He really was in his own league. It seems to me that it's easy to be "quirky" and "different" for the sake of it and basically shock the audience into a laugh. But he didn't do that! You'd laugh first, as in "normal" comedy and only on reflection you'd be shocked at where he took you and how the hell does a mind even come up with that stuff. author: User 862
text:
Since I learned of Sean's passing I've been avoiding videos of him on YT. I still can't believe he's gone. I haven't seen his last episode on cats does countdown until now. There's a magic to seeing for the first time a new episode with Sean and I guess I'll keep trying to save that for as long as I can. Tributes are much much worse, I know I'll start bawling my eyes out if I watch them. I was finally able to bring myself to watch this one, and true enough, I can't stop crying, especially when Lee Mack quoted "I've had a really good life, you know?" I haven't even met Sean. I'm not from the UK. Only found him on YT a few years ago and here I am, devastated with his death.

You have had a good life. Because you've managed to make everyone else's life a little bit better with you in it. Thank you Sean Lock.

author: User 873
text:
It was so tough listening to Bill talk about him. I‚Äôm not saying that the other comics weren‚Äôt friends with Sean because they were. Everyone here has a relationship with Sean outside of a professional capacity. But Bill & Sean were best friends for 40 odd years. They did everything together.

I remember seeing them do a performance at the Edinburgh festival together, must have been in the early 90s. But they were performing together before that with Mark Lamarr & Toby Longworth in the late 80s doing the rubber bishops stuff.

You can see the tears in bills eyes & can see that he‚Äôs taken it worse than anyone. He‚Äôs probably been crying for months about it. Even present date March 2022 & he still regularly tweets photos of them both together saying how much he misses him.

replies.author: Real Detective51
replies.text: @triton62674 maybe, but it just gets old.  I wish comedians weren‚Äôt so afraid of getting canceled.  They used to immune to whatever joke they told, and rightly so.  There‚Äôs a lot of music these days that personify and talk about terrible things and promote living terrible and selfish lives.  I disagree with that, so I just simply don‚Äôt listen it, I don‚Äôt tweet about it, or call for them to be canceled, I just turn it off and don‚Äôt support them monetarily.  Comedy needs to be the same way again. If they joke about a topic you don‚Äôt like, don‚Äôt support them with your attention.  Simple as that. That‚Äôs what I was meaning.   They‚Äôre just too scared.

replies.author: triton62674
replies.text: @Real Detective51 It comes more down to sponsorships and the general image of the network than being woke there's a definite market for it.

replies.author: Real Detective51
replies.text: That‚Äôs how I discovered him.  Being in America, you have to look for most British comedy to find it.  There‚Äôs so much of it here.  Most of it has become so woke it‚Äôs intolerable.  I‚Äôd just discovered Lee Mack looking for new stuff to watch.  My style of comedy as always been quick wit, so of course Lee was quick to pop up in the YouTube search results, and watching his stuff took me down a rabbit hole that led to Sean Lock.  This was the first joke I heard him say and the very first time I‚Äôd heard him speak.  I knew I‚Äôd love him after that.  I‚Äôd never heard of countdown or 8 out of 10 cats before.  It‚Äôs been a fun ride every since.  I‚Äôve seen so much of his work now, I feel like I grew up with him.

author: User 983
text: There are comedians that would make you think, joke about offensive topics, do impersonation, improv, do one liners and are masters of wordplay. I may have found jokes by other comedians funnier but nobody else has that mix of great jokes, a loveable old grumpy goof persona and a willingness to just chat whatever shit he wanted to. In terms of raw entertainment and likeability he really did set the bar.
